name: Bremen
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bremen is famous for the Brothers Grimm fairy tale 'Town Musicians of Bremen' featuring a brave foursome of donkey, dog, cat, and rooster who outwitted robbers. A bronze statue by Gerhard Marcks (1951) graces the Rathaus, and touching the donkey's front hooves is said to make wishes come true. Bremen also houses one of the world's most complete German wine collections in the 600-year-old Ratskeller cellar (since 1405) - no beer is served there!

hero_dishes.name: Kohl und Pinkel
hero_dishes.description: Brown kale served with Pinkel sausage (spicy oatmeal-filled sausage), potatoes, and mustard - Bremen's true national dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: From mid-November to early March, groups embark on 'Kohl und Pinkel Fahrts' (Kohl and Pinkel trips) - countryside outings involving hilarity, odd costumes, barrel organs, and ending with this hearty meal at country inns. Pinkel refers to a special section of pig's intestine used as sausage skin, filled with oatmeal and spices. This ritual meal is quintessentially Bremer, meant to be enjoyed with friends on cold winter days.

hero_dishes.name: Bremer Labskaus
hero_dishes.description: Sailor's hash made with corned beef, potatoes, and beetroot, topped with fried egg, pickled herring, and pickles
hero_dishes.origin_story: This seaman's dish dates back to Bremen's Hanseatic port history. Sailors needed hearty, preserved foods on long voyages, so corned beef, beets, and pickles became staples. The pink-purple hash looks unusual but is deeply satisfying - a one-pot meal designed to stick to your ribs during North Sea storms.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Bremen restaurants, historic seafood houses, Ratskeller

hero_dishes.name: Knipp
hero_dishes.description: Fatty grain sausage made with oats, barley, and pork, browned in a frying pan and served with potatoes or bread
hero_dishes.origin_story: This humble North German specialty uses every part of the pig combined with grains, reflecting the frugal traditions of Hanseatic merchants. It's browned crispy on the outside, creamy inside - the ultimate comfort food on cold Bremen mornings.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Bremen breakfast spots, market stalls, local pubs

hero_dishes.name: Bratheringe (Fried Marinated Herring)
hero_dishes.description: Fresh herring fried then marinated in vinegar, onions, and spices - one of northern Germany's most popular dishes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bremen's proximity to the North Sea meant abundant herring. Frying and pickling preserved the fish before refrigeration, creating a dish that's both tangy and rich. Served cold with bread, it's been a Bremen staple for centuries.

signature_drinks.name: Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Bremen's liquid pride - every third cup of coffee drunk in Germany comes from Bremen
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The first coffee house in the German-speaking world opened in Bremen in 1673. Locals have their own word for cultured coffee enjoyment: 'kaffeesieren' - the art of savoring coffee with conversation. Almost every second imported coffee bean in Germany passes through Bremen's historic port.

signature_drinks.name: German Wine (at Ratskeller)
signature_drinks.description: Selection from 650 exquisite German wine varieties stored in the historic Ratskeller cellars since 1405
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Wine tasting in the ancient Ratskeller cellar is a unique Bremen experience. The cellar houses perhaps the most complete collection of German wines in the world, with some bottles over 100 years old. Locals take pride that NO beer is served here - only wine.

Seasonal traditions are strong: Kohl und Pinkel trips only happen November-March when kale is in season
Marktplatz (Market Square) is the heart of Old Town, with historic merchant houses now transformed into cafes
